awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Metal-Free Production of Olefin Metathesis Polymers and Resins
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I Project will develop a metal-free route to the production of high performance plastics and composites. Specifically, this project focuses on a unique class of materials based upon a thermoset that displays high strength-to-weight ratio and exceptional fracture toughness. A challenge to broader adoption of these materials stems from the current reliance on metal-based reagents and catalysts for their production. The metals impose a significant recurring cost of production, show sensitivity to air, and remain as contaminants in the final products. This innovation provides the first metal-free access to such materials. Additionally, the unique metal-free catalyst system is capable of producing resin and polymer feedstocks that are not available from metal-based reagents, and may offer advantages in processing and performance. The projected commercial impacts of the innovation will be enhanced material performance, lower cost products, and broadened (new) fields of use. The existing market is estimated to be $578M with 4.9% annual growth through 2023.

The intellectual merit of this project is the invention and development of the first metal-free route to olefin metathesis polymers and oligomers. Prior art has demonstrated on small scale the ability to use a unique organocatalyst to produce polymer and resin feedstocks that are easily processable into high performance thermosets and composites. The organocatalyst approach is a divergence from all previous methods of producing materials via olefin metathesis and therefore warrants validation and optimization toward commercial scale-up. The Phase I research aims will include (1) scale-up through the design and implementation of flow reactor technologies, (2) mechanical analyses and product specification sheets for thermoset prototypes, and (3) evaluation of new resins and polymers for use in fiber reinforced composite materials.  The results should be useful commercially and academically.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Ring-opening metathesis polymerization (ROMP) is a powerful synthetic method for converting cycloalkene monomers into high value polymers and materials. For decades, the centerpiece for achieving high efficiency ROMP was the use metal initiators, such as ruthenium, molybdenum, and tungsten salts. In 2015, the Boydston Research Group at the University of Washington discovered a way to conduct ROMP without the use of metals. Further development led to a process in which visible light can be used to drive the polymerization. The photoredox organocatalyzed ROMP enables ready access to oligomeric species and linear (non-crosslinked) polydicyclopentadiene that are difficult to achieve using metal-based initiators. The result is polymers and resins with low molecular weights that can be processed as thermoplastics.

The Boydston Research Group?s discovery at the University of Washington led to the filing of a patent application.  Boydston Chemical Innovations was formed to pursue the science of the discovery and to commercialize the products made from this discovery.  During the time of this NSF Phase I grant, two customers were developed for the technology and US 10,273,327 was granted.  Profits from this grant were used to pay for the application and fees.

The goal of our Phase I STTR was to demonstrate scalability and commercial viability for the metal-free ROMP process, with a focus on poly(dicyclopentadiene) (pDCPD). pDCPD is lightweight, corrosion resistant, and impact resistant, making it a material of choice for vehicle panels and containers. Using photochemical flow chemistry and through optimization of reaction conditions, we have achieved collectively kilogram-scale synthesis of a variety of polymers and copolymers of DCPD. By modifying the ratios of starting materials, we can target specific molecular weights to give products with tunable chemical, thermal, and mechanical properties. In pursuit of our first Grant milestone, we developed procedures to recover and reuse our solvents and unreacted monomers, minimizing both waste and costs for the process. In pursuit of our second Grant milestone, we have also begun preparing molded samples of our products for mechanical testing, so that our polymers can be compared to currently available products. The customer discovery process that we carried out during STTR Phase I enabled us to identify the industry needs that could best be met by our unique products, in fields such as injection molding and additive manufacturing. Establishing partnerships with existing materials companies and research laboratories allows us to have our products tested. In pursuit of our third Grant milestone, we have established chemical synthesis techniques to prepare custom oligomers for customer evaluation and testing. The outcomes achieved during STTR Phase I put us in a position to further improve economics and increase production scale.  Thus, we have completed our Phase I milestones and have applied for Phase II funding to accomplish a new set of milestones.

 


Last Modified: 05/10/2019
Modified by: John Goldstone

por.por_txt_cntn:
Ring-opening metathesis polymerization (ROMP) is a powerful synthetic method for converting cycloalkene monomers into high value polymers and materials. For decades, the centerpiece for achieving high efficiency ROMP was the use metal initiators, such as ruthenium, molybdenum, and tungsten salts. The result is polymers and resins with low molecular weights that can be processed as thermoplastics.

The Boydston Research Group?s discovery at the University of Washington led to the filing of a patent application.  Boydston Chemical Innovations was formed to pursue the science of the discovery and to commercialize the products made from this discovery.  During the time of this NSF Phase I grant, two customers were developed for the technology and US 10,273,327 was granted.  Profits from this grant were used to pay for the application and fees.

In pursuit of our third Grant milestone, we have established chemical synthesis techniques to prepare custom oligomers for customer evaluation and testing. The outcomes achieved during STTR Phase I put us in a position to further improve economics and increase production scale.  Thus, we have completed our Phase I milestones and have applied for Phase II funding to accomplish a new set of milestones.
